transcript:
Therapist: Another helpful tool for your toolbox is coping cards. These are small cards or notes that you can keep with you and refer to when you need a reminder of your adaptive thoughts, strategies, and new core beliefs. For example, you could create a card that says, "Mistakes don't define my worth. I am capable and valuable, even when I'm not perfect." Or, "Progress, not perfection. Every small step counts."

Patient: I like that idea. It's like having a little pep talk in my pocket whenever I need it.

Therapist: Exactly! And you can personalize them based on the thoughts and beliefs that are most helpful for you. You can also create cards with reminders of your favorite stress management techniques or problem-solving steps.

Patient: That's a great idea. I'll definitely make some of those.

Therapist: Wonderful. As we start to wrap up our sessions together, it's also important to think about how you'll support yourself going forward. In addition to using your CBT toolbox, it can be helpful to think about your social support system. Who are the people in your life who you can turn to for encouragement and understanding?

Patient: Well, I have a few close friends who I know I can count on. And my family is pretty supportive, even though they don't always understand what I'm going through.

Therapist: Those sound like great sources of support. It can also be helpful to think about how you can communicate your needs to them. For example, if you're having a tough day and need someone to listen, how can you let them know?

Patient: I guess I could just be honest and tell them that I'm struggling and could use some support. I don't always feel comfortable doing that, but I know it's important.

Therapist: It can definitely be vulnerable to ask for help, but it's a really brave and important thing to do. And remember, your support system doesn't have to be perfect. It's just about having people who care about you and want to be there for you, even if they don't always know exactly what to say or do.

Patient: That's a good point. I don't have to expect them to fix everything, just to be there for me.

Therapist: Exactly. And in addition to your personal support system, there are also professional resources available if you need them. If you find yourself really struggling or feeling like you need extra support, don't hesitate to reach out to a therapist or counselor. There's no shame in asking for help when you need it.

Patient: I'll keep that in mind. It's good to know I have options if I need them.

Therapist: Absolutely. And remember, you've done an amazing job in our work together. You've learned and practiced so many valuable skills, and you've made really meaningful changes in your life. I have so much confidence in your ability to continue that progress and handle whatever challenges come your way.

Patient: Thanks, Nova. It's been really helpful to have your support and guidance through this process.

Therapist: It's been an honor to work with you, Alejandro. I'm so proud of all the hard work you've done and the progress you've made. Remember, you have all the tools and skills you need to continue that progress. And if you ever need a reminder or some extra support, you can always refer back to your toolbox and your support system.

Patient: I will. Thank you for everything.

Therapist: Before we end our session, let's do a quick check-in. How are you feeling right now?

Patient: I'm feeling pretty good, actually. A little nervous about ending our sessions, but also excited to keep practicing what I've learned.

Therapist: That's great to hear. It's totally normal to feel a little nervous about ending therapy, but I have so much faith in your ability to keep making progress. And remember, you can always come back for a "booster" session if you need a little extra support down the road.

Patient: That's good to know. I'm definitely going to miss our sessions, but I feel like I'm ready to keep working on this on my own.

Therapist: I completely understand. It's bittersweet to end our work together, but I'm so excited to see all the amazing things you'll accomplish. Before we wrap up, let's assign some homework for the week. I'd like you to continue practicing your thought records, stress management techniques, and self-compassion exercises. And if you have time, try creating a few coping cards to add to your toolbox.

Patient: Sounds good. I'll definitely do that.

Therapist: Wonderful. And if any challenges come up, remember to use your problem-solving skills and reach out for support if you need it. You've got this, Alejandro.

Patient: Thanks, Nova. I'll do my best.

Therapist: I know you will. And remember, progress isn't always a straight line. There will be ups and downs, but what matters is that you keep going and keep practicing. Every small step counts, and every challenge is an opportunity to learn and grow.

Patient: I'll try to remember that. It's not always easy, but I know it's worth it.

Therapist: It absolutely is. And I'm always here if you need a little reminder or some extra support. You've done an incredible job, Alejandro, and I'm so grateful to have been a part of your journey.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I'm really grateful for all your help and support.

Therapist: It's been my pleasure. I'm so proud of you and all the progress you've made. Keep up the amazing work, and don't hesitate to reach out if you need anything.

Patient: I will. Thank you again for everything.

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed:
  - Reviewed progress with thought records, stress management techniques, and self-compassion exercises
  - Discussed challenges with self-compassion and problem-solving
  - Developed a personalized "toolbox" of CBT skills and strategies
  - Explored options for ongoing support after therapy ends
  - Celebrated progress and discussed plans for maintaining gains
- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Thought records: Continued practicing identifying and reframing perfectionistic thoughts
  - Stress management techniques: Deep breathing and progressive muscle relaxation
  - Self-compassionate self-talk: Continued practicing challenging self-critical thoughts with kindness and understanding
  - Problem-solving: Discussed breaking challenges down into smaller, more manageable steps
  - Coping cards: Introduced as reminders of adaptive thoughts, strategies, and new core beliefs
- Homework assigned:
  - Continue using thought records to identify and reframe perfectionistic thoughts
  - Practice stress management techniques, such as deep breathing and progressive muscle relaxation
  - Practice self-compassionate self-talk whenever noticing self-critical or perfectionistic thoughts
  - Create coping cards with reminders of adaptive thoughts, strategies, and new core beliefs
  - Use problem-solving skills to break down challenges into smaller steps
- Patient's progress:
  - Showing increased insight into the connection between perfectionism and core beliefs about worthiness
  - Willing to challenge perfectionistic thoughts and practice generating alternative thoughts based on the new core belief
  - Engaging in behavioral experiments to gather evidence against perfectionistic beliefs
  - Expressing a more balanced and self-compassionate perspective on mistakes and imperfections
  - Developing a personalized "toolbox" of CBT skills and strategies
  - Identifying sources of social support and professional resources for ongoing support
- Challenges:
  - Continuing to manage perfectionistic thoughts and self-critical beliefs in the face of stress and challenges
  - Practicing self-compassion and reframing core beliefs consistently
  - Overcoming fear of judgment and rejection in social situations
  - Navigating the transition to independence after therapy ends
- Depression symptoms:
  - Persistent feelings of sadness and emptiness
  - Lack of motivation
  - Fatigue
  - Decreased appetite and weight loss
  - Difficulty concentrating
  - Irritability
  - Feelings of overwhelm
  - Sleep difficulties
- Important personal details:
  - Hispanic male, 31 years old
  - Military family background
  - Divorced
  - Lives alone
  - Works long hours at a demanding job
  - Passionate about languages and writing
- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Old core belief: "I need to be perfect to be worthy."
  - New core belief: "I am worthy and valuable regardless of my performance or achievements."
  - Intermediate belief: "If I'm not the best, I'm a failure."
- Plan for next session:
  - As this is the final session, no plan for next session. Patient will continue to practice skills independently and seek support as needed.
